summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with a Federal Bureau of Prisons Correctional Officer Lieutenant regarding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in August 2019. The interview focuses on staffing, procedures, counts, rounds, communication failures regarding Epstein's cellmate requirement, and the lieutenant's actions and knowledge during the relevant shifts.

connections.description: The lieutenant reported to the captain, who was her immediate supervisor. She states she and other lieutenants told the captain multiple times that Epstein should have been on the more secure 10 South unit.
The lieutenant supervised CO Thomas during her shift on August 9-10, 2019. She spoke with him during her rounds and he called in a count issue to her.
The lieutenant supervised CO Noel during her shift on August 9-10, 2019. She spoke with Noel briefly after the incident.
Both were Correctional Officers assigned to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on the morning watch shift of August 10, 2019, and were responsible for counts and rounds together.

The interviewee relieved Lieutenant as the operations lieutenant on the evening of August 9, 2019. She suggests he should have informed her if he knew about Epstein's cellmate requirement and vacancy.
The psychologist sent an email on July 30, 2019, to a group that included the lieutenant, stating Epstein needed a cellmate. The lieutenant states she never saw or read this email.

events.title: Epstein's prior suicide attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell in the SHU after an apparent suicide attempt. The responding lieutenant found him lying on the floor, seemingly unresponsive but breathing, and he was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Email from psychology on cellmate requirement
events.description: A psychologist sent an email stating inmate Jeffrey Epstein was being taken off psych observation and needed to be housed with an appropriate cellmate.

events.title: Epstein's cellmate removed from MCC
events.description: Inmate (Epstein's cellmate) was removed from his cell around 8:30 a.m. for court and was gone from the institution by about 1:30 p.m., leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found deceased
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: Midnight count discrepancy
events.description: During the midnight count on August 10, COs Thomas and Noel reported a count of 73 but noted an inmate was in R&D. The lieutenant instructed them to recount, which should have resulted in a count of 72. A corrected count slip was supposedly created but may not have been picked up.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, sworn interview with a BOP lieutenant regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the circumstances surrounding it.

keyFacts: The interviewed lieutenant was unaware of the July 30, 2019, email from psychology requiring Jeffrey Epstein to have a cellmate, stating she never saw it due to being overwhelmed with other duties and institutional chaos.

The lieutenant asserts that Jeffrey Epstein, as a high-profile inmate who had previously attempted suicide, should have been placed on the 10 South unit (which has cameras in each cell and constant staff monitoring) rather than in the general Special Housing Unit (SHU).

During the midnight count on August 10, 2019, there was a discrepancy because an inmate from SHU was being housed in R&D. COs Thomas and Noel initially reported a count of 73 but noted the inmate in R&D. The lieutenant instructed a recount to reflect 72, but a corrected count slip may not have been collected.

The lieutenant states that the MCC was severely understaffed at the time, with correctional officers routinely working 16+ hour days due to mandatory overtime, which impacted the ability to perform all duties and communicate effectively.

The lieutenant had no knowledge that cameras in the SHU were not working on the night of Epstein's death and was not aware of any policy violations by COs Thomas and Noel regarding counts or rounds, expressing surprise at the suggestion they might have falsified them.
